body.p: No matter which homeostatic feedback loop is diagrammed, they all include a stimulus that changes to initiate and provide feedback to the control center. Click the correct types of stimuli involved in the feedback homeostatic regulation of hormone production for each characteristic or situation below (check all that apply):
Involves some kind of chemical stimulating the release of hormone into blood:

response.feedback: Correct. Typically the chemical is a solute or ion in body fluids that stimulates a chemoreceptor, often located in the endocrine gland to stimulate hormone production.
Correct. The hormone is the chemical messenger binding to its specific target cell receptor in another endocrine gland, stimulating it to produce another different hormone.
Correct. The neurotransmitter doesnâ€™t travel far but still binds to its specific receptor to stimulate the release of a hormone into the blood.

part.hint: All three types of stimuli will affect some kind of receptor.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The changing solute or ion would need to circulate to contact the sensor.

Correct. The neuron releases its neurotransmitter directly at the gland it is stimulating.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it would take a while, the gland can respond as soon as the change has been detected.

Incorrect. The endocrine gland would be stimulated quickly by nervous stimulation.

question.body: Homeostatic mechanisms stimulated by changes in body fluid composition (humoral) often involve more than one hormone in a negative feedback loop. Why would this be typical? For example: insulin decreases blood glucose while glucagon increases blood glucose; parathyroid hormone increases blood calcium levels while calcitonin from thyroid decreases blood calcium in children.

part.explanation: Stimulating opposite responses to maintain body fluid homeostasis will need to involve different target cells and metabolic responses. Because each hormone has a specific receptor and specific effect on its target cells, it will take different hormones to maintain this humoral component within homeostatic range. As it increases, it would stimulate release of one hormone but not the other; as it decreases, it would stimulate release of the other hormone.
